name: Ziggurat of Ur
longDescription:
Tell el-Muqayyar, Dhi Qar Province, Iraq The Ziggurat of Ur (Sumerian: E-temen-nigur, "House whose foundation creates terror") is the best-preserved
                ziggurat in ancient Mesopotamia and one of the most important monuments from the world's earliest urban
                civilizations. Built around 2100 BCE by King Ur-Nammu of the Third Dynasty of Ur, this massive stepped
                temple tower was dedicated to Nanna (Akkadian: Sin), the moon god who was the patron deity of Ur.
                Standing originally at approximately 30 meters (100 feet) tall, the ziggurat dominated the flat
                Mesopotamian plain and served as the religious heart of one of the ancient world's greatest cities -
                the biblical "Ur of the Chaldees," traditional birthplace of Abraham.

primaryLocation.name: Tell el-Muqayyar, Dhi Qar Province, Iraq
